items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The language in Proposition 30 requires that all California community college districts have sole authority to determine how the moneys received from the Educational Protection Account are spent in the school or schools within its jurisdiction, provided:
The appropriate governing board or body shall make these spending determinations in open session of a public meeting of the governing board or body and shall not use any of the funds from the Education Protection Account for salaries or benefits of administrators or any other administrative costs
Shall annually publish on its Internet Website an accounting of how much money was received from the Education Protection Account and how that money was spent
Shall, in addition to all other requirements of law, ascertain and verify through the annual independent audit whether the funds provided from the Education Protection Account have been properly disbursed and expended as required by this section.
Attached for reference is the April 3, 2013, California Community Colleges Chancellor's Office Accounting Advisory, to assist districts with compliance for the language in Proposition 30, as noted above.
	 
This Board action contains the recommended spending plan for the District's Proposition 30 allocation for the 2013-14 fiscal years per the proposition's guidelines and the Accounting Advisory (see attached report).
	 
For the 2014-15 adopted budget, we budgeted to receive $19,627,922.  It is relevant to note that this is not new, additional funding to the District.  The District will apply these designated funds as needed to the instructional and student support categories included in the spending plan until the amount received from the EPA is reached.  No funds will be applied to administrator's salaries or benefits, or any other administrative costs.  The District will post on its website an accounting of what the final 2013-14 allocation of EPA funds was to the District and how it was expended.  This will not take place until late September after the financial books for 2013-14 have been closed.  Additionally, the expenditure of the funds will be included in the CCFS-311 report to the state chancellor's office and the annual financial audit will include verification that the funds were used as required by Proposition 30.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
 Joni Hayes, Director, Budget Operations, x6261

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Foundation for the California Community Colleges (FCCC) negotiates special pricing on behalf of the California Community Colleges for software and hardware products.  The District participates in the Microsoft Campus Agreement plan through the FCCC, which allows us to purchase an annual site license agreement for Microsoft products at a substantially reduced price based on our FTE faculty/staff count, less the percentage of faculty on overload teaching status and reduced by the number of faculty and staff on leave. The average cost savings compared to the normal Academic or Select license is approximately 60-70%.  It provides a 20% reduction in the license cost from the retail group purchase price.  ComputerLand of Silicon Valley is the vendor that administers this program.  The cost to the district, for this year, is $94,013.00 based on a Foothill College cost of $34,539.00 and a De Anza cost of $59,474.00. This is the first year of a three-year contract the FCCC has with Microsoft.
	 
The agreement also allows our employees to purchase selected Microsoft applications for their personal use at a substantially reduced price through the FCCC (College Buys).  
	 
Because the purchase is through the FCCC there is no need to participate in a formal bid process.  This first year contract will be October 1, 2014, through September 30, 2015. 
	 
Submitted by:
Joe Moreau, Vice Chancellor, Technology
Additional contact names:
Sharon Luciw
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On July 8, 2014, the Fremont Union High School District Board of Trustees passed resolutions authorizing two measures for the November 4, 2014, ballot. Measure J would renew the district's existing $98 parcel tax for an additional six years, beginning July 1, 2016, without increasing the cost or changing the structure of the proposal voters first approved in 2004. Measure K would authorize the sale of up to $295 million in bonds for the purpose of raising money for specific school facilities projects. The tax rate estimate for the Measure K facilities bond measure is approximately $21 per $100,000 of assessed property value.
	 
Fremont Union High School District projects an enrollment increase of 18 percent between 2010 and 2020. The parcel tax renewal would pay for core programs and staff salaries while the construction bond measure would help the district build 51 new classrooms to accommodate increased enrollment, renovate older facilities, and improve access to technology.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor, Chancellor

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The dive pool tower at the De Anza College dive pool is deteriorating, therefore making it a safety hazard and a liability to the District. Debris has recently fallen into the pool and the surrounding area; portions of the pool and immediate area are now blocked off from use.  The 5-meter platform has not been regularly used for several years and the 10-meter platform has not been used for instruction or rental for approximately 20 years.
	 
This project includes the complete demolition of the concrete diving tower aboveground and its associated steel stairs and railings.  The concrete pad will be patched to match the existing pool deck. The contractor shall be required to completely protect the dive pool, surrounding pool deck and diving boards, adjacent buildings, and the site. Time is of the essence and the project shall be completed between the last week of summer’s campus closure and the start of the second week of instruction this fall. The legal advertisement for this bid required that the direct contractor have either an “A” – General Engineering Contractor license or “B” General Building Contractor, each with a listed “C-21” Building/Moving Demolition Contractor which is a contractor that specifically demolishes structures. 
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on August 5 and August 12, 2014. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the Daily Pacific Builder as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on August 26, 2014 in the Purchasing Services office. Three (3) contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:
BID RESULTS
Contractor
Base Bid 
Proposal Amount
R. C. Benson & Sons, Inc.
$131,000
Buccaneer Demolition Inc.
$258,792
Rodan Builders Inc.
$317,000
	 
The apparent low bidder, R. C. Benson & Sons, Inc. (Benson) listed a demolition contractor, however that contractor does not possess the required “C-21” Building/Moving Demolition Contractor license; rather it possesses a “C-61/D06” Concrete Related Services license which is a limited specialty contractor that is confined to the activities to that field or scope of operations. District staff consulted with its legal counsel Mr. Phillip Jaret of Jaret & Jaret Attorneys at Law regarding the listing of a “C-61/D06” licensed demolition subcontractor by Benson instead of the required “C-21” demolition subcontractor.  It is the opinion of staff and legal counsel that a “C-21” demolition contractor  must perform this scope of work due to the complexities surrounding the removal of the debris and the protection of surrounding areas and structures.  Furthermore, the listing of a “C-61/D06” subcontractor as opposed to a “C-21” subcontractor, which was a requirement of the bid, is not a minor irregularity or immaterial matter that can be waived and the Bid Proposal submitted by Benson must be rejected as it is not responsive to the bid call.
	 
The second apparent low responsive and responsible bidder, Buccaneer Demolition Inc. (Buccaneer) does possess the required “B” and “C-21” licenses to perform the work and has confirmed that its bid price of $258,792 is true and accurate for the work as specified. Buccaneer successfully completed "The Pierce Building" demolition in San Jose and a soft demolition library project for Santa Clara County.   
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, Ext. 6166
Additional contact names:
  Donna Jones Dulin, Tom Armstrong, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
  Yes

Background and Analysis:
	 
Information was provided to the Board of Trustees on December 7, 2009, and January 19, 2010, concerning the use of a Lease-Leaseback construction procurement process for Measure C projects.  The information included a discussion of the legal aspects of the process as well as the likely risks and benefits associated with construction using the authority provided under the Education Code section 81335. On August 31, 2010, a default judgment was issued by the Santa Clara County Superior Court, which confirmed the validity of the use of this procurement process.  Since that time the Board has approved the use of Lease-Leaseback procurement for several projects including the Media and Learning Center and the Advanced Technology Center renovation project at De Anza College; the FHDA Education Center; and the Physical Sciences & Engineering Center and Library & ISC renovation project at Foothill College.
	 
At the August 25, 2014, meeting, the Board of Trustees reviewed and approved a concept design for a new district office building located in Lot 7 on the Foothill College campus. The procurement process for this project will be consistent with the process used for previously approved projects, and it will include the same key decision/Board approval steps.  The Board will be requested to review and approve key decisions and actions in the procurement process over a period of time.  Target dates for key actions associated with the project are as follows:
February, 2015 - Approval of the Lease-Leaseback contractor based upon a Request for Qualifications and Request for Proposals process
February, 2015 - Award of a pre-construction services agreement for the 
Lease- Leaseback contractor
Late 2015 - Approval of a Site Lease and a Facilities Lease with the 
Lease- Leaseback contractor including a guaranteed maximum price for construction
	 
The project will be funded by Measure C project #404 – New District Offices.
	 
Submitted by:
  Steve Kitchen, Executive Director of Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
  Art Heinrich, Ext. 6295; Pam Grey, Ext. 6166
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: The Executive Director of Facilities and Operations recommends that the Board approve the initiation of a construction procurement process under the Lease-Leaseback provision of Education Code section 81335 for the project subject to the subsequent Board approvals as noted.
